panels.description: Displays the number of offline log directories in Kafka brokers. A value greater than zero indicates potential disk failures or mount issues.
panels.title: Offline Log Directories

panels.description: Displays the log flush rate and flush time in Kafka brokers. High flush time may indicate disk I/O bottlenecks, while low flush rate may increase data loss risk.
panels.title: Log Flush Rate & Time (ms) (quantile: 0.999)

panels.description: Displays the longest time taken by Kafka's log cleaner process to clean a log segment. High values may indicate disk I/O bottlenecks or inefficient log segment configurations.
panels.title: Log Cleaner Max Clean Time

panels.description: The number of under-replicated partitions (| ISR | < | current replicas |). Replicas that are added as part of a reassignment will not count toward this value. Alert if the value is greater than 0.
panels.title: Under Replicated Partitions

panels.description: The number of partitions whose in-sync replicas count is less than minIsr.
panels.title: Under Min. ISR Partitions

panels.description: Displays the rate of failed TLS or SASL handshakes in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate incorrect client configurations, expired certificates, or network issues.
panels.title: Kafka Failed Handshake Rate

panels.description: Displays the rate of failed authentication attempts in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate incorrect client configurations, expired credentials, or network issues.
panels.title: Kafka Failed Authentication Rate

panels.description: Displays the average time (in nanoseconds) taken for authentication in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate slow authentication mechanisms, overloaded brokers, or network latency issues.
panels.title: Kafka Authentication Time (Avg)

panels.description: Displays the average request size (in bytes) received by Kafka brokers. High values may indicate large batch sizes or increased network traffic, potentially leading to performance bottlenecks.
panels.title: Kafka Request Size (Avg)

panels.description: Displays the rate of outgoing bytes per second from Kafka brokers. A high value may indicate increased consumer traffic or possible broker overload.
panels.title: Top 5 Consume Rate

panels.description: Displays the rate of incoming bytes per second to the Kafka brokers. A high value may indicate increased producer traffic or possible broker overload.
panels.title: Top 5 Produce Rate

panels.description: Displays the total number of producer requests received per second. A high value indicates increased producer traffic, which may impact broker performance if it exceeds processing capacity.
panels.title: Total Producer Requests Per Second (by Topic)

panels.description: Displays the total number of fetch requests received per second. High values may indicate increased consumer traffic, overloaded brokers, or inefficient partition distribution.
panels.title: Total Fetch Requests Per Second (by Topic)

panels.description: In general, this is the best place to look to know if your brokers are potentially being strained. Intermittent spikes in this value could indicate that individual clients are causing problems in the way theyre making requests.
panels.title: Req/s (Total)

panels.description: Becomes slow with all hosts, hence select only one host. API 'version' field ignored.
panels.title: Req/s (For each request type)

panels.description: Displays the 99.9th percentile latency of log fetch operations in Kafka brokers. High values indicate slow disk reads, overloaded brokers, or excessive consumer request traffic.
panels.title: Kafka Log Fetch Latency (p99.9)

panels.description: The lag in number of messages per follower replica. This is useful to know if the replica is slow or has stopped replicating from the leader and if the associated brokers need to be removed from the In-Sync Replicas list.
panels.title: Fetcher(Follower) Lag

panels.description: Displays the rate at which replicas are removed from the ISR (In-Sync Replicas) set. A high value indicates potential replication issues or follower replicas falling behind the leader.
panels.title: Kafka ISR Shrinks Per Second

panels.description: Displays the number of failed ISR (In-Sync Replicas) updates per second. High values indicate replication issues, network delays, or configuration problems with min.insync.replicas.
panels.title: Failed ISR Updates Per Second

panels.description: Displays the total number of fetch requests received from follower brokers per second. A high value may indicate frequent replication fetches, network congestion, or slow replication.
panels.title: Total Follower Fetch Requests Per Second (by Topic)

panels.description: Displays the number of fetch requests received from follower brokers per second. A high value may indicate frequent replication fetches, network congestion, or slow replication.
panels.title: Fetch from Follower Requests Per Second

panels.description: Displays the incoming byte rate for replication in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate active replication processes, increased broker load, or network congestion.
panels.title: Replication Bytes In Per Second

panels.description: Displays the outgoing byte rate for replication in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate active replication processes, increased broker load, or network congestion.
panels.title: Replication Bytes Out Per Second

panels.description: In most cases, a high value can imply slow local storage or the storage is a bottleneck. One should also investigate LogFlushRateAndTimeMs to know how long page flushes are taking, which will also indicate a slow disk. In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.
panels.title: Follower - LocalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply a slow network connection. For fetch request, if the remote time is high, it could be that there is not enough data to give in a fetch response. This can happen when the consumer or replica is caught up and there is no new incoming data. If this is the case, remote time will be close to the max wait time, which is normal. Max wait time is configured via replica.fetch.wait.max.ms and fetch.max.wait.ms.
panels.title: Follower - RemoteTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Follower - TotalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Follower - RequestQueueTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough network threads or the network cant dequeue responses quickly enough, causing back pressure in the response queue.
panels.title: Follower - ResponseQueueTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply the zero-copy from disk to the network is slow, or the network is the bottleneck because the network cant dequeue responses of the TCP socket as quickly as theyre being created. If the network buffer gets full, Kafka will block.
panels.title: Follower - ResponseSendTimeMS

panels.description: Displays the number of failed producer requests per second in Kafka. High values may indicate broker-side errors, authentication issues, or topic unavailability.
panels.title: Failed Produce Requests (Per Sec)

panels.description: Displays the 99.9th percentile latency of log appends in Kafka brokers. High values indicate slow disk writes, broker overload, or excessive producer request traffic.
panels.title: Kafka Log Append Latency (p99.9)

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Producer - TotalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough network threads or the network cant dequeue responses quickly enough, causing back pressure in the response queue.
panels.title: Producer - ResponseQueueTimeMS

panels.description: In most cases, a high value can imply slow local storage or the storage is a bottleneck. One should also investigate LogFlushRateAndTimeMs to know how long page flushes are taking, which will also indicate a slow disk. In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.
panels.title: Producer - LocalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply a slow network connection. For fetch request, if the remote time is high, it could be that there is not enough data to give in a fetch response. This can happen when the consumer or replica is caught up and there is no new incoming data. If this is the case, remote time will be close to the max wait time, which is normal. Max wait time is configured via replica.fetch.wait.max.ms and fetch.max.wait.ms.
panels.title: Producer - RemoteTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Producer - RequestQueueTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply the zero-copy from disk to the network is slow, or the network is the bottleneck because the network cant dequeue responses of the TCP socket as quickly as theyre being created. If the network buffer gets full, Kafka will block.
panels.title: Producer - ResponseSendTimeMS

panels.description: Displays the number of failed fetch requests per second in Kafka. High values may indicate consumer or broker-side errors, authentication issues, or topic unavailability.
panels.title: Failed Fetch Requests (Per Sec)

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Consumer - TotalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough IO threads or the CPU is a bottleneck, or the request queue isn't large enough. The request queue size should match the number of connections.
panels.title: Consumer - RequestQueueTimeMS

panels.description: In most cases, a high value can imply slow local storage or the storage is a bottleneck. One should also investigate LogFlushRateAndTimeMs to know how long page flushes are taking, which will also indicate a slow disk. In the case of FetchFollower requests, time spent in LocalTimeMs can be the result of a ZooKeeper write to change the ISR.
panels.title: Consumer - LocalTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply a slow network connection. For fetch request, if the remote time is high, it could be that there is not enough data to give in a fetch response. This can happen when the consumer or replica is caught up and there is no new incoming data. If this is the case, remote time will be close to the max wait time, which is normal. Max wait time is configured via replica.fetch.wait.max.ms and fetch.max.wait.ms.
panels.title: Consumer - RemoteTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply there aren't enough network threads or the network cant dequeue responses quickly enough, causing back pressure in the response queue.
panels.title: Consumer - ResponseQueueTimeMS

panels.description: A high value can imply the zero-copy from disk to the network is slow, or the network is the bottleneck because the network cant dequeue responses of the TCP socket as quickly as theyre being created. If the network buffer gets full, Kafka will block.
panels.title: Consumer - ResponseSendTimeMS

panels.description: The number of partitions that dont have an active leader and are therefore not writable or readable. Alert if value is greater than 0.
panels.title: Offline Partitions

panels.description: In KRaft mode, the number of fenced, but registered brokers as observed by this controller. This metric is always 0 in ZooKeeper mode.
panels.title: Fenced Broker Count

panels.description: Number of partitions being replicated unexpectedly based on current cluster metadata. Should remain at 0 in a healthy state.
panels.title: Stray Partitions Count

panels.description: The count of topic partitions for which the leader is not the preferred leader.
panels.title: Preferred Replica Imbalance Count

panels.description: Displays the 1/5/15-minute Linux load average of Kafka brokers. High values may indicate sustained CPU overload or resource contention over time.
panels.title: Kafka Server Load Avg

targets.expr:
(
    sum by(instance, instance) (irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{_cluster="$cluster",_environment="$environment",_role=~"broker", job="node-exporter",mode!="idle"}[$__rate_interval])) / 
    on(instance) group_left sum by (instance, instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{_cluster="$cluster",_environment="$environment",_role=~"broker",job="node-exporter"}[$__rate_interval])))
) * 100

panels.description: This graph is a percentage from 0 to 100 of how busy the I/O threadsalso known as the Request Handler Threadsare. The metric is key in alerting on how loaded a broker is.
panels.title: Heap Usage

panels.description: This graph is a percentage from 0 to 100 of how busy the I/O threadsalso known as the Request Handler Threadsare. The metric is key in alerting on how loaded a broker is.
panels.title: GC Time

panels.description: Displays the total number of garbage collection (GC) events in the JVM. A high rate may indicate frequent garbage collection, which can impact application performance.
panels.title: JVM GC Collection Count

panels.description: Displays the number of JVM threads in different states (RUNNABLE, TIMED_WAITING, BLOCKED, etc.). High values in BLOCKED or TIMED_WAITING states may indicate contention issues or performance bottlenecks.
panels.title: JVM Threads by State

panels.description: Displays the current number of active threads in the JVM. A high value may indicate excessive concurrency, inefficient thread management, or potential memory leaks.
panels.title: JVM Current Threads

panels.description: A higher count means that the queue is congested, so its better to have a lower value. In conjunction with NetworkProcessorAvgIdlePercent, you can get a good idea of how busy the full Kafka request pipeline is.
panels.title: Request Queue Size

panels.description: Displays the size of the Kafka response queue. A consistently high value may indicate slow network response times, overloaded brokers, or high client request traffic.
panels.title: Response Queue Size

panels.description: Displays the average time (in nanoseconds) spent on I/O operations in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate disk or network bottlenecks, leading to potential performance degradation.
panels.title: Kafka I/O Time (Avg)

panels.description: Displays the average time (in nanoseconds) spent waiting for I/O operations in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate disk or network bottlenecks, leading to performance degradation.
panels.title: Kafka I/O Wait Time (Avg)

panels.description: Displays the total network I/O rate in Kafka brokers. High values may indicate increased producer and consumer activity, leading to potential network bottlenecks.
panels.title: Kafka Network I/O Rate

panels.description: Displays the number of pending requests in Kafka's socket server pipeline. A high value may indicate overloaded brokers, insufficient request handlers, or network bottlenecks.
panels.title: Request Pipelined Count

panels.description: A higher count means that the queue is congested, so its better to have a lower value. In conjunction with NetworkProcessorAvgIdlePercent, you can get a good idea of how busy the full Kafka request pipeline is.
panels.title: Request Pool Usage

panels.description: This metric describes the percentage of time that your network threads are busy. Should be below 70%.
panels.title: NetworkProcessor Usage

panels.description: Displays the number of request errors per second in Kafka. A high value may indicate authentication failures, client misconfigurations, or broker issues affecting request handling.
panels.title: Network Request Errors Per Second

panels.description: Displays the amount of data (in bytes) rejected per second by Kafka brokers. High values indicate issues with message size limits, replica fetch limits, or authorization failures.
panels.title: Bytes Rejected Per Sec

title: Kafka Broker Overview
description: Comprehensive Grafana dashboard for monitoring Kafka brokers (KRaft).
